hero.content:
The Philippines’ forgotten siege: Marawi’s long road to recovery
thenewhumanitarian.org

It has been almost six years since hundreds of thousands of civilians were displaced by the country’s longest urban battle. Why have so few returned?
thenewhumanitarian.org

primary.lead: Jeepney Drivers Strike Over Modernization Plans
primary.title: Drivers strike over plan to remove aging Philippine jeepneys
primary.description: MANILA, Philippines (AP) — Philippine transport groups launched a nationwide strike Monday to protest a government program drivers fear would phase out traditional jeepneys, which have become a cultural icon , and other aging public transport vehicles.

secondary.title: Philippines Jeepney strike drives home modernisation concerns
secondary.description: President instructs agencies to reconsider proposals amid concerns about the effect on drivers’ livelihoods.

secondary.title: Transport groups terminate strike
secondary.description: Transport groups ended their strike on Wednesday after Malacañang agreed to review the Public Utility Vehicle Modernization Program (PUVMP).

secondary.title: Colorful, Iconic Jeepneys May Soon Be Off the Road in the Philippines
secondary.description: The passenger vehicles have been ubiquitous for decades. The way the government wants to replace them with pricey new minibuses is rankling operators.

carousel.title: Drugs, jacuzzis and a horse: the anarchic Philippines prison where anything can be bought
carousel.description: After raids at the New Bilibid prison identified thousands of contraband goods, the management of the country’s prisons is in the spotlight

carousel.title: About 61% of overseas foreign workers from the Philippines are women, says statistics authority
carousel.description: Overseas foreign workers from the Philippines are often subjected to long working hours and exploitation. CNBC's JP Ong reports.

carousel.title: How the CIA Used 'Vampires' to Fight Communism in the Philippines
carousel.description: Back in the Cold War craziness of the 1950s, a CIA operative in the Philippines used the local folklore myth of the blood-sucking aswang to try and scare off communist rebels. Did it work?

carousel.title: SF's Queer, Filipina-Owned Chocolate Shop Celebrates Love Year-Round
carousel.description: Kokak Chocolates makes organic truffles and bars that taste like kalamansi, pizza and even ramen.
